dataset.title: Data on weights and lengths from retrospective growth analysis of different stem age classes of Betula nana ramets from the Arctic LTER Nutrient and Warming manipulations in mosit acidic tussock tundra at 1995, Toolik Lake, AK.

abstract.para: This data file contains the data on weights and lengths from retrospective growth analysis of different stem age classes of Betula nana ramets from the Arctic LTER Nutrient and Warming manipulations in moist acidic tussock tundra at Toolik Lake.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications

A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:
Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Moist Acidic Tussock Tundra LTER Experimental plots

description.para: DATA FILE ENTERED BY: Syndonia Bret-Harte
Version 2 Updated the atttributes and added DAS control
Version 3: Upadte LTERNET Data Access server proxy link for Excel and comma delimited data files. Changed from knb to das in url.
Version 4: Updated metadata form to newer version (without site sheet). CH 24 Jan 2013 Updated to newer metadata with site sheet. CH March 2013.
Version 5: Checked keywords against the LTER network preferred list and replaced non-preferred terms. Jim L 17Feb14

para.literalLayout:
The experiment is the LTER nutrient by warming factorial treatments, which has 4 randomized blocks (Shaver et al.?). We randomly collected 3 individual ramets of Betula nana from each treatment within each block. The most recent 15 years of growth were analyzed for each ramet. Stems were cut and cross-sections made by hand with a razor blade. Ages were determined by staining the sections with 1% phloroglucinol in 20% HCl and counting the growth rings using a compound light microscope at 100x magnification. Stems were separated into different age classes trying to get at least one piece with same age on both ends for each age class. Lengths and weights of pooled segments for a given age class were determined after drying samples at 70 degrees C for 48 hours. Because no external bud scars were usually visible, the boundary between age classes of stems usually could not be known with certainty. The lengths and weights of stem pieces that overlapped one year boundary were assigned half to one age and half to the next. Lengths and weights of pieces that overlapped more than one age class were assigned to the different age classes by dividing by one less than the number of years covered, and assigning half that amount to the two end pieces and the whole amount to intervening years, to avoid a bias toward the end pieces. When the end of the piece was the bottom of a branch, and therefore that boundary was known with certainty, the piece was divided by x.5, where x is one less than the number of years that the piece overlapped. Half that amount was assigned to the upper part of the segment, where the boundary was not known with certainty, while the whole amount was assigned to the other year classes covered by that piece, including the oldest piece. These procedures avoided a bias in assigning weight and length disproportionately to the years where a cut was made. Betula nana makes two types of stem segments, short shoots and long shoots. Long shoots could be aged by making stem cross-sections, but short shoots could not because they have so little secondary growth. However, the maximum age of short shoots is one year less than the long shoot to which they are attached. Short shoot weight and length was assigned by dividing the total weight or length by the maximum age of those shoots and assigning that to each year class up to that age. Short shoots occasionally convert to long shoots, in which case they put on secondary growth and behave like a long shoot from then on (but obviously the stem segments covering the period of short shoot growth do not increase in length). These conversions from short to long shoots were classified separately in the data table.
Notes: Betula nana rep 1 from block 3 was excluded because it was diseased. No other data is missing. Data in columns with stippled headings were measured data, other columns are calculated from that data. Data from pieces that were overlapping age classes but were not conversions are entered in measured data columns as additions onto the original numbers (e.g. the formula shows =x+y+z).
See paper: Bret-Harte, M.S., G.R. Shaver, and F.S. Chapin III. 2002. Primary and secondary stem growth in arctic shrubs: implications for community response to environmental change. Ecology 90: 251-267.

project.title: Arctic Long-Term Ecological Research (ARC LTER) Program

para.literalLayout:
The goal of Arctic LTER project is to predict the future ecological characteristics of the site based upon our knowledge of the controls of ecosystem structure and function as exerted by physical setting and geologic factors, climatic factors, biotic factors, and the changes in fluxes of water and materials from land to water. To achieve this goal the Arctic LTER uses several approaches:
Long-term monitoring and surveys of natural variation of ecosystem characteristics in space and time. Includes: climate, plant communities and productivity, thaw depth, stream flow, chemistry of streams and lakes, temperatures of streams and lakes, lake chlorophyll lake productivity, zooplankton abundance.
Experimental manipulation of ecosystems for years and decades. Includes: tundra warming, shading, and fertilizing, grazer exclusions, fertilization of lakes and streams, addition and subtraction of predators.
Synthesis of results and predictive modeling at ecosystem and watershed scales. Includes: stream N cycling, lake physics, bioenergetics of fish populations, water movement and transfer of DOC and nutrients from land to water, soil respiration, cycling and storage of C in tundra under different scenarios of future climates.

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grants #DEB-981022, 9211775, 8702328; #OPP-9911278, 9911681, 9732281, 9615411, 9615563, 9615942, 9615949, 9400722, 9415411, 9318529; #BSR 9019055, 8806635, 8507493. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The Arctic LTER research site (68°N and 149°W) is in the foothills region of the North Slope of Alaska and includes the entire Toolik Lake watershed and the adjacent watershed of the upper Kuparuk River, down to the confluence of these two watersheds. This area is typical of the northern foothills of the Brooks Range, with continuous permafrost, no trees, a complete snow cover for 7 to 9 months, winter ice cover on lakes, streams, and ocean, and cessation of river flow during the winter. Tussock tundra vegetation of sedges and grasses mixed with dwarf birch and low willows form the dominant vegetation type with areas of drier heath tundra on ridge tops and other well-drained sites as well as areas of river-bottom willow communities.

dataTable.entityDescription: Data on weights and lengths from retrospective growth analysis of different stem age classes of Betula nana ramets from the Arctic LTER Nutrient and Warming manipulations in mosit acidic tussock tundra at 1995, Toolik Lake, AK.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Treatment (control, fertilized, greenhouse, greenhouse*fertilized)
Treatment coded numerically (1,2,3,4)
Block number (1-4)
Replicate number (1-3)
Year when that stem age class was created
Stem age classes, whose age is counted backward from the present in this study (1995 = year 0, 1994 = year 1, etc)
# of long shoot branches in that age class
# of long shoot branches + number of short shoot branches that subsequently converted into long shoots (conversions) in that age class
Length, in mm, of all long shoots in that age class
Weight, in mg, of all long shoots in that age class
Age classes that overlap one year boundary

textDomain.definition: Age classes that overlap one year boundary

attribute.attributeDefinition: Length in mm of all long shoot stem segments that overlap the given age classes
Half of the variable just mentioned
Length + LS boundary length/2 for each age class (mm)
Weight in mm of all long shoot stem segments that overlap the given age classes (mg)
Half of the variable just mentioned
Weight + LS boundary weight/2 for each age class (mg)
total length of an age class divided by the number of long shoots in that age class
total weight of an age class divided by the number of long shoots in that age class
total weight of an age class divided by the total length of that age class
Age classes
Number of branches that were converted short shoots in that age class

Length of conversions in that age class (mm) = The sum of the total length of a conversion divided by the number of years it was a short shoot, for all conversions that were short shoots during that year.
Weight of conversions in that age class (mg) = The sum of the total weight of a conversion divided by the number of years it was a short shoot, for all conversions that were short shoots in that year

Total number of conversion events, from the maps. (Not all conversions were saved, so this number will not necessarily reflect the numbers in the "conversion #" column, which only refers to those conversions that were weighed and measured.
total number of conversion events (from the maps) that occurred after the LTER treatment began.
total length of structural branches = sum of total length LS and conversion length for each age class
total weight of structural branches = sum of total weight LS and conversion weight for each age class
length per segment of structural branches, = total lnth struct divided by total number of structural branches
weight per segment of structural branches = total wt struct divided by total number of structural branches
total weight of structural branches divided by total length of structural branches

textDomain.definition: total weight of structural branches divided by total length of structural branches

attribute.attributeDefinition: maximum age of short shoots, same as Age above
number of short shoots having that maximum age
total length of short shoots in that maximum age class (mm)
total weight of short shoots in that maximum age class (mg)

number of short shoots which covered a range of years not going to the present, but did not convert to long shoots (for example, the portion of a short shoot below a branch point into several more short shoots
length of the short shoots covering a range of years not going to the present (see note for # SS 1-year span above)
weight of short shoots covering a range of years not going to the present (see note for # SS 1-year span, above)
length of short shoots in a maximum age class divided by the number in that class
average length of short shoots per year = length of short shoots in a maximum age class divided by the age of that class
length of short shoots in a maximum age class divided by the number of shoots in that class and the age of the class

The sum of the average short shoot length per year from that age to the oldest living short shoots, plus any short shoot lengths from the "1-year span" short shoots. This is the total amount of short shoot length put on in a given year. As an example, the short shoot length put on in year 3 will be the average length per year of the maximum age 3 short shoots, and also the contributions in year 3 from the maximum age 4, 5, 6,... etc. short shoots, since they would also be living and growing in year 3, but not the 1 or 2 year old short shoots, since they hadn't been formed yet.
weight of short shoots in a maximum age class divided by the number in that class
average weight of short shoots per year = weight of short shoots in a maximum age class divided by the age of that class
weigh of short shoots in a maximum age class divided by the number of shoots in that class and the age of the class

The sum of the average short shoot weight per year from that age to the oldest living short shoots, plus any short shoot weights from the "1-year span" short shoots. This is the total amount of short shoot weight put on in a given year. As an example, the short shoot weight put on in year 3 will be the average weight per year of the maximum age 3 short shoots, and also the contributions in year 3 from the maximum age 4, 5, 6,... etc. short shoots, since they would also be living and growing in year 3, but not the 1 or 2 year old short shoots, since they hadn't been formed yet.

The number of currently surviving short shoots that were growing in a given year. Calculated analogously to the total surviving SS weight and number per year, as the sum of all short shoots of a given age up to the oldest surviving short shoots, as all of those would be growing during that year.
Length of conversions plus total surviving short shoot length in that year
Weight of conversions plus total surviving short shoot weight in that year

textDomain.definition: Weight of conversions plus total surviving short shoot weight in that year

attribute.attributeDefinition: the values of the age classes that had living short shoots, used to calculate the next variable...
the age of the oldest living short shoot for that ramet
weight of the year 0 (current year's) leaves and stems (mg)
the number of short shoots initiated in the current year
the total number of living short shoots, of all ages
the number of long shoots initiated in the current year
the number of year 0 long shoots divided by the sum of year 0 long shoots and total living SS
the number of year 0 long shoots divided by the sum of year 0 long shoots and year 0 short shoots

The total number of living growing points = sum of year 0 long shoots, total living short shoots, and inflorescences that were not included in one of the preceding categories. (Current year's inflorescences were not included in current year's short or long shoots, but next year's inflorescence buds were included in current year's long or short shoots)
The total weight of structural branches plus total surviving ss weight per year
The total length of structural branches plus total surviving ss lnth per year
The total number of short and long shoot branches, = total # structural branches + total #surviving ss per year
cumulative number of long shoots segments = sum of the number of branches in that age class and the number in all younger age classes.
analogous sums for structural branches and total branches (total # (ls + ss))
analogous sums for structural branches and total branches (total # (ls + ss))
analogous sums for length values for the different age classes- see discussion for cumulative numbers, above.
analogous sums for length values for the different age classes- see discussion for cumulative numbers, above.
analogous sums for length values for the different age classes- see discussion for cumulative numbers, above.
analogous sums for weight values for the different age classes- see discussion for cumulative numbers, above.
analogous sums for weight values for the different age classes- see discussion for cumulative numbers, above.
analogous sums for weight values for the different age classes- see discussion for cumulative numbers, above.
the fraction of the total cumulative weight that is short shoots, = 1 - (cum wt struct/cum wt total)
The total number of attached dead branches in the ramet (only those that have at least some long shoot component, not just dead short shoots) from the maps
The number of dead branches divided by the cumulative total weight of stems (year 15 of cum wt total)
The total number of dead growing points, = sum of long shoots and short shoots on those attached dead branches (does not include dead short shoots attached to living stems)
Total number of dead growing points divided by the cumulative total weight in year 15

The total number of dead long shoots in the attached dead branches. Since the age structure of the dead branches was not determined, this is the number of long shoot branch points in the attached dead branches
As above, the dead structural branches divided by year 15 of cum wt total

The number of branch points of long shoots in the living wood. Not the same as the number of segments in each age class, because sometimes long shoots convert back to being short shoots, in which case they do not show up in subsequent (younger) age classes.

attribute.attributeName: total dead struct/(total live + dead struct)
attribute.attributeLabel: total dead struct/(total live + dead struct)
attribute.attributeDefinition: the number of attached dead long shoot branch points divided by the total live and dead branch points, a measure of mortality
The number of inflorescences, either current year or next year's buds, depending on the replicate number.
The weight of inflorescences, either current year or next year's buds, depending on the replicate number.
The weight divided by number of inflorescences, either current year or next year's buds, depending on the replicate number.
the age of the living branch to which the dead was attached
the age at the base of the dead branch, if known

textDomain.definition: the age at the base of the dead branch, if known

attribute.attributeDefinition: -1 if the dead branch was a lateral, 0 if it was not

textDomain.definition: -1 if the dead branch was a lateral, 0 if it was not

attribute.attributeDefinition: total number of growing points (short and long shoots) on that dead branch

textDomain.definition: total number of growing points (short and long shoots) on that dead branch

attribute.attributeDefinition: the total number of long shoot branch points in that attached dead branch

textDomain.definition: the total number of long shoot branch points in that attached dead branch

attribute.attributeDefinition: How long ago that attached branch system died, if known

textDomain.definition: How long ago that attached branch system died, if known

attribute.attributeDefinition: total weight of all attached dead branches

textDomain.definition: total weight of all attached dead branches
